Benedict planned on 5 March 2008, to meet with Muslim scholars and religious leaders autumn 2008 at a Catholic-Muslim seminar in Rome.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/03/05/pope.muslims/index.html|title=Pope to hold seminar with Muslims|publisher=}} That meeting, the "First Meeting of the [[Catholic-Muslim Forum]]," was held from 4–6 November 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.zenit.org/article-24175?l=english |title=Final Statement of Catholic-Muslim Forum |publisher=Zenit |date=6 November 2008 |accessdate=2 October 2011 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628vo62lE?url=http://www.zenit.org/article-24175?l=english |archivedate=2 October 2011 |df= }} On 9 May 2009, Benedict visited the King Hussein Mosque, [[Amman]], Jordan where he was addressed by [[Prince Ghazi bin Muhammad]].Saleh, Fakhri [http://en.qantara.de/Signs-of-Hope/9472c9571i1p642/ "Arab Reactions to the Pope's Visit Signs of Hope"] [[Qantara.de]] 18 May 2009. Retrieved 3 February 2011 [https://www.webcitation.org/628wO0yyM?url=http://en.qantara.de/Signs-of-Hope/9472c9571i1p642/ WebCitation archive] ====Tibetan Buddhism==== The [[Tenzin Gyatso, 14th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]] congratulated Pope Benedict XVI upon his election,{{cite web|url=http://www.phayul.com/news/article.aspx?id=9643&t=1|title=His Holiness the Dalai Lama Greets New Pope|publisher=}} and visited him in October 2006 in the Vatican City. In 2007, China was accused of using its political influence to stop a meeting between the Pope and the Dalai Lama.[http://www.adnkronos.com/AKI/English/Religion/?id=1.0.1604471683 "Italy: China blamed for absence of Papal audience for Dalai Lama"], [[Adnkronos]], 27 November 2007. Retrieved 19 June 2009 ====Indigenous American beliefs==== While visiting Brazil in May 2007, "the pope sparked controversy by saying that native populations had been 'silently longing' for the Christian faith brought to South America by colonizers."{{cite news|title=Pope Softens Remarks on Conversion of Natives |first=Ian |last=Fisher |authorlink=Ian Fisher (journalist) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/23/world/europe/23cnd-pope.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=23 May 2007 |accessdate=2 October 2011 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628R2PlYB?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/23/world/europe/23cnd-pope.html |archivedate=2 October 2011 |df= }} The Pope continued, stating that "the proclamation of Jesus and of his Gospel did not at any point involve an alienation of the [[Pre-Columbian era|pre-Columbus]] cultures, nor was it the imposition of a foreign culture." The then [[President of Venezuela]], [[Hugo Chávez]] demanded an apology, and an indigenous organisation in Ecuador issued a response which stated that "representatives of the Catholic Church of those times, with honourable exceptions, were accomplices, deceivers and beneficiaries of one of the most horrific genocides of all humanity." Later, the Pope, speaking Italian, said at a weekly audience that it was "not possible to forget the suffering and the injustices inflicted by colonizers against the indigenous population, whose fundamental human rights were often trampled."Fisher, Ian [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/23/world/americas/23iht-pope.4.5843368.html "Pope tries to quell anger over speech he gave in Brazil"], ''The New York Times'', 23 May 2007. Retrieved 2 October 2011 [https://www.webcitation.org/628ReRoEF?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/23/world/americas/23iht-pope.4.5843368.html WebCitation archive] ====Hinduism==== While visiting the United States on 17 April 2008, Benedict met with [[International Society for Krishna Consciousness]] representative [[Radhika Ramana Dasa]];Smith, Peter [http://news.iskcon.com/node/963 "ISKCON Scholar To Meet With The Pope"] ISKCON News 31 March 2008. Retrieved 2 October 2011 [https://www.webcitation.org/628S3wBeB?url=http://news.iskcon.com/node/963 WebCitation archive] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121195133/http://news.iskcon.com/node/963 |date=21 November 2008 }} a noted [[Hindu]] scholar{{cite web|url=http://news.iskcon.com/node/988 |title=ISKCON News |work=ISKCON News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706140348/http://news.iskcon.com/node/988 |archivedate=6 July 2008 }} and disciple of [[Hanumatpreshaka Swami]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bhaktivedantacollege.com/index.php?p=article&g=33|title=Bhaktivedanta College|work=Bhaktivedanta College}} On behalf of the Hindu American community, Radhika Ramana Dasa presented a gift of an [[Om]] symbol to Benedict.{{cite web|url=http://news.iskcon.com/node/991/2008-04-18/iskcon_scholar_greets_pope_behalf_of_us_hindus |title=ISKCON News |work=ISKCON News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606082910/http://news.iskcon.com/node/991/2008-04-18/iskcon_scholar_greets_pope_behalf_of_us_hindus |archivedate=6 June 2013 }}Alexander, David [https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/04/15/us-pope-usa-interfaith-idUSN1438604520080415 "Despite missteps, pope reaching out to other faiths"] Reuters 15 April 2008. Retrieved 2 October 2011 [https://www.webcitation.org/628Tts0gw?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2008/04/15/us-pope-usa-interfaith-idUSN1438604520080415 WebCitation archive] ===Apostolic ministry=== {{Main|List of journeys of Pope Benedict XVI}} [[File:Popemobil Mai 2007.jpg|thumb|Pope Benedict XVI in a [[Mercedes-Benz]] [[popemobile]] in [[São Paulo, Brazil]]]] As pontiff, Benedict XVI carried out numerous Apostolic activities including journeys across the world and in the Vatican. Benedict travelled extensively during the first three years of his papacy. In addition to his travels within Italy, Pope Benedict XVI made two visits to his homeland, Germany, one for [[World Youth Day]] and another to visit the towns of his childhood. He also visited Poland and Spain, where he was enthusiastically received.Israely, Jeff [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1211537,00.html "The Pope Squares Off With Spain's Secular Champion"] "No doubt Benedict was buoyed by the enthusiastic welcome he received in Valencia." ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' 9 July 2006. Retrieved 20 November 2010 [https://www.webcitation.org/624eWFwqQ?url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0%2C8599%2C1211537%2C00.html WebCitation archive] His visit to Turkey, an overwhelmingly Muslim nation, was initially overshadowed by the [[Pope Benedict XVI Islam controversy|controversy about a lecture he had given at Regensburg]]. His visit was met by nationalist and Islamic protestersMoore, Molly. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/26/AR2006112600191.html "Turks Protest Pope's Coming Visit"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', 27 November 2006. Retrieved 13 May 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/624epITtc?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/26/AR2006112600191.html WebCitation archive] and was placed under unprecedented security measures.{{cite web|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/world/massive-security-for-popes-turkey-visit-286901.html|title=Massive security for Pope's Turkey visit|work=Breaking News}} However, the trip went ahead and Benedict made a joint declaration with [[Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I]] in an attempt to begin to heal the rift between the Catholic and Orthodox churches. In 2007, Pope Benedict visited Brazil in order to address the Bishops' Conference there and canonize Friar Antônio Galvão, an 18th-century [[Franciscan]]. In June 2007, Benedict made a personal pilgrimage and pastoral visit to [[Assisi]], the birthplace of [[St. Francis of Assisi|St. Francis]]. In September, Benedict undertook a three-day visit to Austria,Vatican Radio [http://storico.radiovaticana.org/en1/storico/2007-09/153562_pope_benedict_xvi_going_to_vienna.html "Pope Benedict XVI Going to Vienna"] 7 September 2007. Retrieved 26 January 2011 [https://www.webcitation.org/624fltp2u?url=http://storico.radiovaticana.org/en1/storico/2007-09/153562_pope_benedict_xvi_going_to_vienna.html WebCitation archive] during which he joined Vienna's [[Chief Rabbi]], Paul Chaim Eisenberg, in a memorial to the 65,000 Viennese Jews who perished in Nazi death camps.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6982878.stm|title=BBC NEWS – Europe – Pope honours Austrian Jewish dead|publisher=}} During his stay in Austria, he also celebrated Mass at the Marian shrine [[Mariazell]] and visited [[Heiligenkreuz Abbey]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bundespraesident.de/SharedDocs/Reden/DE/Christian-Wulff/Reden/2011/09/110922-Papst-Begruessung.html|title=www.bundespraesident.de: Der Bundespräsident / Reden / Begrüßung Seiner Heiligkeit Papst Benedikt XVI. zum offiziellen Besuch in Deutschland|publisher=}} [[File:20080416 Benedict XVI George W Bush birthday.jpg|thumb|left| Pope Benedict XVI celebrates his 81st birthday with U.S. President [[George W. Bush]] and his wife, [[Laura Bush|Laura]]. [[The White House]], Washington D.C.]] In April 2008, Pope Benedict XVI made his [[Pope Benedict XVI's visit to the United States|first visit to the United States]] since becoming pope.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/US/04/15/pope.us/index.html|title=Pope Benedict XVI begins first U.S. tour|publisher=}} He arrived in Washington, DC where he was formally received at the [[White House]] and [[List of meetings between the Pope and the President of the United States|met privately]] with U.S. President [[George W. Bush]].Associated Press [http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,351460,00.html "Bush, Thousands of Fans Welcome Pope at White House on His Birthday"], Fox News, 16 April 2008. Retrieved 13 May 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/624hRMwKh?url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0%2C2933%2C351460%2C00.html WebCitation archive] While in Washington, the pope addressed representatives of US Catholic universities, met with leaders of other world religions, and celebrated Mass at the Washington Nationals' [[Nationals Park|baseball stadium]] with 47,000 people.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a4XCdKnx9gfw |title=Pope Benedict Says Mass Before 47,000 in New Washington Stadium |author=Nadine Elsibai |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |date=17 April 2008 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/624hpIQi8?url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a4XCdKnx9gfw |archivedate=30 September 2011 |df= }} The Pope also met privately with victims of sexual abuse by priests. The Pope travelled to New York where he addressed the [[United Nations General Assembly]].{{UN document |docid=A-62-PV.95 |body=General Assembly |type=Verbotim Report |session=62 |meeting=95 |page=3 |anchor=pg003-bk01 |date=18 April 2008 |speakername=Pope Benedict XVI | speakernation=Holy See |accessdate=1 July 2008 }} [https://www.webcitation.org/624iDmYqS?url=http://www.undemocracy.com/generalassembly_62/meeting_95 WebCitation archive] Also while in New York, the Pope celebrated Mass at [[St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York|St. Patrick's Cathedral]], met with disabled children and their families, and attended an event for Catholic youth, where he addressed some 25,000 young people in attendance.Duin, Julia. [http://washingtontimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080420/NATION/168699792/1001 "Youths revel in pope's message"], ''[[The Washington Times]]'', 20 April 2008. Retrieved 13 May 2008. [https://www.webcitation.org/624igDsSy?url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2008/apr/20/youths-revel-in-popes-message/ WebCitation archive] On the final day of the Pope's visit, he visited the [[World Trade Center site]] and later celebrated Mass at [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]].Vitello, Paul {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/21/us/nationalspecial2/21pope.html |title=After Ground Zero Prayer, Pope Ministers to 60,000 in Stadium |accessdate=29 September 2011 |date=21 April 2008 |work=The New York Times |first=Paul |last=Vitello |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/624jReVR0?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/21/us/nationalspecial2/21pope.html |archivedate=30 September 2011 |df= }} In July 2008, the Pope travelled to Australia to attend [[World Youth Day 2008]] in Sydney. On 19 July, in [[St Mary's Cathedral, Sydney|St. Mary's Cathedral]], he made an apology for child sex abuse perpetrated by the clergy in Australia.{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jtGYmNq72j_-TNnXfLbSdMgiTPMQ |title=Pope apologises for 'evil' of child sex abuse |agency=Agence France-Presse |publisher=Google |date=18 July 2008 |accessdate=2 February 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/624jyAeEL?url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jtGYmNq72j_-TNnXfLbSdMgiTPMQ |archivedate=30 September 2011 |df= }}{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/burningIssues/idUKSYD1805020080719 |title=Pope apologises for Church sex abuse|agency=Reuters|date=19 July 2008 |accessdate=2 February 2010| first=Philip | last=Pullella}} [https://www.webcitation.org/6265QjCp8?url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2008/07/19/uk-pope-australia-abuse-idUKSYD1805020080719 WebCitation archive] On 13 September 2008, at an outdoor Paris Mass attended by 250,000 people, Pope Benedict XVI condemned the modern [[materialism]] – the world's love of power, possessions and money as a modern-day plague, comparing it to [[paganism]].{{cite web|url=http://www.huliq.com/3257/68370/pope-condemns-materialism-pagan |title=Pope Condemns Materialism as "Pagan" |publisher=Huliq.com |date=14 September 2008 |accessdate=2 February 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6265kmyFE?url=http://www.huliq.com/3257/68370/pope-condemns-materialism-pagan |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }}[https://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2008-09-13-Pope-France_N.htm "Pope drinks water from Lourdes spring"] ''[[USA Today]]'' 15 September 2008. Retrieved 26 January 2011 [https://www.webcitation.org/62664vwY5?url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2008-09-13-Pope-France_N.htm WebCitation archive] In 2009, he visited Africa (Cameroon and Angola) for the first time as pope. During his visit, he suggested that altering sexual behavior was the answer to Africa's AIDS crisis, and urged Catholics to reach out and convert believers in [[Magic (paranormal)|sorcery]]. He visited the Middle East (Jordan, Israel and Palestine) in May 2009. Pope Benedict's main arena for pastoral activity was the Vatican itself, his Christmas and Easter homilies and Urbi et Orbi are delivered from St Peter's Basilica. The Vatican is also the only regular place where Benedict XVI traveled via motor without the protective bulletproof case common to most popemobiles. Despite the more secure setting, Pope Benedict was victim to security risks several times inside Vatican City. On Wednesday, 6 June 2007 during his General Audience a man leapt across a barrier, evaded guards and nearly mounted the Pope's vehicle, although he was stopped and Benedict seemed to be unaware of the event. On Thursday, 24 December 2009, while Pope Benedict was proceeding to the altar to celebrate Christmas Eve Mass at [[St Peter's Basilica]], a woman later identified as 25-year-old [[Susanna Maiolo]], who holds Italian and Swiss citizenships, jumped the barrier and grabbed the Pope by his [[Papal vestments|vestments]] and pulled him to the ground. The 82-year-old fell but was assisted to his feet and he continued to proceed towards the altar to celebrate Mass. [[Roger Etchegaray]], 87, the vice-dean of the College of Cardinals, fell also and suffered a hip fracture. Italian police reported that the woman had previously attempted to accost the Pope at the previous Christmas Eve Mass, but was prevented from doing so.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2009-12-24-pope-christmas-mass_N.htm |title=Pope OK after woman knocks him down at Mass |work=USA Today |date=25 December 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6266OJJzm?url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2009-12-24-pope-christmas-mass_N.htm |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }}Winfield, Nicole [http://www.toledoblade.com/Religion/2009/12/25/Pope-delivers-Christmas-blessing-after-fall.html "Pope delivers Christmas blessing after fall"] ''[[News & Record (Greensboro)|News & Record]]'' 25 December 2009. Retrieved 26 January 2011 [[File:Pope Benedict XVI in Malta.JPG|thumb|Pope Benedict XVI in [[Balzan]], Malta]] In his [[homily]], Pope Benedict forgave Susanna Maiolo{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/2009/12/25/2009-12-25_pope_benedict_forgives_.html |title=Pope Benedict forgives Susanna Maiolo one day after she knocked him down during Christmas Eve Mass |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |date=25 December 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2010 | first=Samuel | last=Goldsmith}} [https://www.webcitation.org/62670E3kc?url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2009-12-25/news/17940995_1_christmas-day-mass-pope-benedict-berlusconi WebCitation archive] and urged the world to "wake up" from selfishness and petty affairs, and find time for God and spiritual matters. [[File:Pope Benedict XVI in Zagreb 04.jpg|thumb|Pope Benedict XVI in [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]]]]Between 17 and 18 April, Pope Benedict made an Apostolic Journey to the Republic of Malta. Following meetings with various dignitaries on his first day on the island, 50,000 people gathered in a [[drizzle]] for Papal Mass on the granaries in [[Floriana]]. The Pope also met with the [[Maltese people|Maltese]] youth at the [[Valletta]] Waterfront, where an estimated 10,000 young people turned up to greet him.{{cite web |title=Wrap-up: Pope Benedict's historic Malta visit ends|work=[[The Times (Malta)|The Times of Malta]]|date=18 April 2010|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100418/papal-visit/pope-benedicts-historic-malta-visit-ends|accessdate=21 April 2010}} [https://www.webcitation.org/62688oVsW?url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100418/papal-visit/pope-benedicts-historic-malta-visit-ends.303399 WebCitation archive] During his visit the Pope was moved to tears while expressing his shame at cases of abuse on the island during a 20-minute meeting with victims. ===Sexual abuse in the Catholic Church=== {{See also|Catholic sex abuse cases}} Prior to 2001, the primary responsibility for investigating allegations of sexual abuse and disciplining perpetrators rested with the individual dioceses. In 2001, Ratzinger convinced John Paul II to put the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith in charge of all investigations and policies surrounding sexual abuse in order to combat such abuse more efficiently.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/faith/article7086738.ece |work=The Times |location=London |title=John Paul 'ignored abuse of 2,000 boys' |first1=Bojan |last1=Pancevski |first2=John |last2=Follain |date=4 April 2010 |accessdate=22 May 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6269S63LN?url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/faith/article7086738.ece |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }}{{cite web |last=Berry |first=Jason |url=http://ncronline.org/news/accountability/money-paved-way-maciels-influence-vatican |title=Money paved way for Maciel's influence in the Vatican |work=[[National Catholic Reporter]] |date=6 April 2010 |accessdate=14 June 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6269nT9DT?url=http://ncronline.org/news/accountability/money-paved-way-maciels-influence-vatican |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }} According to [[John L. Allen, Jr.]], Ratzinger in the following years "acquired a familiarity with the contours of the problem that virtually no other figure in the Catholic Church can claim" and "driven by that encounter with what he would later refer to as 'filth' in the Church, Ratzinger seems to have undergone something of a 'conversion experience' throughout 2003–04. From that point forward, he and his staff seemed driven by a convert's zeal to clean up the mess".{{cite web |last=Allen |first=John L |url=http://ncronline.org/news/accountability/will-ratzingers-past-trump-benedicts-present |title=Will Ratzinger's past trump Benedict's present? |work=National Catholic Reporter |date=17 March 2010 |accessdate=12 September 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/626AFMiCm?url=http://ncronline.org/news/accountability/will-ratzingers-past-trump-benedicts-present |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }} In his role as Head of the CDF, he "led important changes made in Church law: the inclusion in canon law of internet offences against children, the extension of child abuse offences to include the sexual abuse of all under 18, the case by case waiving of the statute of limitation and the establishment of a fast-track dismissal from the clerical state for offenders."{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/columnists/guest_contributors/article7076344.ece |work=The Times |location=London |title=The Church is not trying to cover anything up |first=Vincent |last=Nichols |date=26 March 2010 |accessdate=22 May 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/626AtZBZ6?url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/columnists/guest_contributors/article7076344.ece |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }} As the Head of the CDF, Ratzinger developed a reputation for handling these cases. According to Charles J. Scicluna, a former prosecutor handling sexual abuse cases, "Cardinal Ratzinger displayed great wisdom and firmness in handling those cases, also demonstrating great courage in facing some of the most difficult and thorny cases, ''sine acceptione personarum'' (without exceptions)".According to [[John L. Allen, Jr.]], Ratzinger in the following years "acquired a familiarity with the contours of the problem that virtually no other figure in the Catholic Church can claim" and "driven by that encounter with what he would later refer to as 'filth' in the Church, Ratzinger seems to have undergone something of a 'conversion experience' throughout 2003–04. From that point forward, he and his staff seemed driven by a convert's zeal to clean up the mess". [http://ncronline.org/news/accountability/will-ratzingers-past-trump-benedicts-present Will Ratzinger's past trump Benedict's present?]{{cite web |url=http://www.catholicnews.sg/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4151%3Apromoter-of-justice-at-doctrine-of-faith-on-paedophilia&catid=196%3Avis-vatican-information-service&Itemid=127 |title=Promoter of Justice at Doctrine of Faith on Paedophilia |publisher=Catholic News |date=13 March 2010 |accessdate=14 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/626BDWnJx?url=http://www.catholicnews.sg/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4151:promoter-of-justice-at-doctrine-of-faith-on-paedophilia&catid=196:vis-vatican-information-service&Itemid=127 |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }} One of the cases Ratzinger pursued involved Father [[Marcial Maciel Degollado]], a Mexican priest and founder of the Legion of Christ, who had been accused repeatedly of sexual abuse. Biographer Andrea Tornielli suggested that Cardinal Ratzinger had wanted to take action against Marcial Maciel Degollado, but that John Paul II and other high-ranking officials, including several cardinals and notably the Pope's influential secretary [[Stanisław Dziwisz]], prevented him from doing so.{{cite news |work=The Irish Independent | first=Richard | last=Owen |url=http://www.independent.ie/world-news/europe/vatican-tries-to-shift-blame-for-abuse-on-to-john-paul-26646654.html |title=Vatican tries to shift blame for abuse on to John Paul – Europe, World News |date=3 April 2010 |accessdate=15 December 2015}} According to [[Jason Berry]], [[Angelo Sodano#Relationship with Legion of Christ|Angelo Sodano]] "pressured" Cardinal Ratzinger, who was "operating on the assumption that the charges were not justified", to halt the proceedings against Maciel in 1999{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalcatholicreporter.org/update/bn051806.htm |title=Vatican restricts ministry of Legionaries priest founder |work=National Catholic Reporter |first=John L. |last=Allen Jr. |date=18 May 2006 |accessdate=14 June 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/626CEqFEX?url=http://www.nationalcatholicreporter.org/update/bn051806.htm |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }} When Maciel was honored by the Pope in 2004, new accusers came forward and Cardinal Ratzinger "took it on himself to authorize an investigation of Maciel" After Ratzinger became pope he began proceedings against Maciel and the [[Legion of Christ]] that forced Maciel out of active service in the Church. On 1 May 2010 the Vatican issued a statement denouncing Maciel's "very serious and objectively immoral acts", which were "confirmed by incontrovertible testimonies" and represent "true crimes and manifest a life without scruples or authentic religious sentiment." Pope Benedict also said he would appoint a special commission to examine the Legionaries' constitution and open an investigation into its lay affiliate [[Regnum Christi]].Donadio, Rachel [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/02/world/europe/02legion.html "Pope Reins In Catholic Order Tied to Abuse"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 2 May 2010 [https://www.webcitation.org/626DBuZRI?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/02/world/europe/02legion.html WebCitation archive] Cardinal Christoph Schönborn explained that Ratzinger "made entirely clear efforts not to cover things up but to tackle and investigate them. This was not always met with approval in the Vatican".{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-04-04/uk/28124994_1_sexual-abuse-boys-pontiff |title=Pope John Paul ignored abuse of 2,000 boys: Report |work=The Times of India |date=4 April 2010 |accessdate=12 September 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/626DgxVWK?url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-04-04/uk/28124994_1_sexual-abuse-boys-pontiff |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df= }} According to Schönborn, Cardinal Ratzinger had pressed John Paul II to investigate [[Hans Hermann Groër]], an Austrian cardinal and friend of John Paul accused of sexual abuse, resulting in Groër's resignation.
